oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Chet Atkins Interviewed by Bob Allen in 1982 Side One
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of Bob Allen interviewing Chet Atkins. The recording takes place on 05-21-82.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Chet Atkins
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One - (0:00) -- Bob Allen asks Chet Atkins about "Prairie Home Companion". (1:24) -- Bob Allen asks Chet Atkins to sum up the appeal of "Praire Home Companion." (2:38) -- Chet Atkins describes the situational humor of Garrison Keillor. (3:58) -- Bob Allen asks Chet Atkins about his recent departure from RCA. (4:50) -- Chet Atkins talks about producing for Roger Whittaker. Chet goes on to describe how complex producing methods have dulled his love for producing albums for others. (7:23) -- Bob Allen asks Chet Atkins how many shows he plays per year. Chet responds "about 30." (8:23) -- Bob Allen discusses how much country music changed from the 1950's to the 1980's. Bob then asks Chet his perspective on this change. (10:06) -- "It makes me sad sometimes to hear some of the music that is supposed to be country.." - Chet Atkins. (10:20) -- Bob Allen asks Chet about whether he feels sorry about putting strings on country records. (11:30) -- "The only way you really do something great is do something different, get away from the trend.. When everybody's going north, go south." - Chet Atkins (13:06) -- Bob Allen asks about the first RCA studio at 1525 McGavock, before they moved to Studio B on 17th in 1958. (13:45) -- Bob Allen asks about the electronics Chet Atkins is currently interested in.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Atkins, Chet;
